Memorandum       To:    Martha's Vineyard Commission                                       Date:   July 31, 2013
                        Box 1447 Old Stone Building
                        Oak Bluffs, MA 02557
                                                                                    Project No.:   72451.00


               From:    Randall C. Hart                                                      Re:   Stop & Shop Expansion, Tisbury, MA
                        Director; Transportation Planning                                          Response to HSH Peer Review Response
                        & Engineering, LD                                                          Traffic Impact and Access Study

                        Matthew Kealey P.E., PTOE
                        Project Manager


             This memorandum has been prepared to provide additional information and response to the July 11,
             2013 Howard/Stein-Hudson Associates, Inc. peer review letter prepared for the Martha's Vineyard
             Commission (MVC). For ease of review, the comments, questions, and suggestions from the July 11th
             peer letter are summarized below in italics and the corresponding response is provided below. A copy
             of the peer review letter is also provided in the Appendix for informational purposes.

             Traffic Data Collection
             Comment: In our initial peer review letter, we recommended that the Commission request that the
             Applicant collect new count data at the Five Corners intersection over the Memorial Day holiday
             weekend in May in order to confirm the peak seasonal factor. We also recommended that the
             Commission ask the Applicant to conduct ATR counts on Beach Road and/or State Road for
             comparison with MVC historical data to determine a more appropriate seasonal factor. The Applicant
             did not collect either of these data, citing a math error in HSH's initial calculations as the reasoning
             for not providing them. We are still skeptical that the traffic count data collected in January 2013 have
             been appropriately adjusted to account for the seasonality of traffic on Martha's Vineyard. The MVC
             staff are currently in the process of collection new count data at and around Five Corners. Now that
             the DRI review process is into the peak summer season, we request that the Commission ask the
             Applicant to conduct new summer traffic counts.

             Response:

             Per the request to perform additional traffic counts during the peak season after the July 4th holiday,
             additional turning movement counts (TMCs) were completed at all study area intersections on Thursday
             July 18, 2013 for the weekday evening peak period and on Saturday, July 20, 2013 for the Saturday
             midday peak period. An automatic traffic recorder (ATR) count was also completed on Water Street
             from Friday July 19 through Saturday July 20, 2013.

             The overall TMC peak hour volumes were compared between the January 2013 and July 2013 counts.
             When compared to the original counts completed in January 2013, the July TMC weekday evening
             peak hour is 28% higher overall and the Saturday midday peak hour is 37% higher overall. The ATR
             counts were 46% higher during the weekday evening peak hour and 45% higher during the Saturday
             midday peak hour than the January 2013 ATR at the same location. In contrast, the original adjustment



             \\vhb\proj\Providence\72451.00\docs\memos\Response To HSH Revised Peer Review.docx 
Date:  July 30, 2013                                                                                      2 
Project No.:  72451.00 
      
    factor that was applied to the January traffic counts to create peak summer traffic conditions was 66%.
    So on a cumulative basis, use of the 66% adjustment factor is more conservative than using the actual
    traffic counts collected during peak summer season. However, since certain movements at a couple of
    intersections along Water Street were substantially different, the updated analysis provided in this
    document utilized the unadjusted July (2013) traffic volumes for existing, no-build, and build
    conditions. However, to provide a conservative assessment, the adjustment factor previously applied to
    the traffic generation for the Stop & Shop facility was maintained in the updated analyses. The
    summarized analysis results are provided in Table 1 below.

    In addition, the Martha's Vineyard Commission (MVC) completed various spot TMC counts within the
    month of July at the following study area intersections and times which were provided to the Proponent:

               Main Street at Spring Street / Norton Street on Tuesday July 2nd, 8:00 ­ 10:00 AM;
               Water Street at Norton Lane on Wednesday July 10th, 1:30 ­ 2:30 PM;
               State Road at Main Street on Thursday July 18th, 2:30 ­ 3:30 PM;
               "Five Corners" on Wednesday July 17th, 3:45 ­ 4:45 PM;
               "Five Corners" on Saturday July 20th, 10:00 AM ­ 12:00 PM;
               Main Street at Union Street on Tuesday July 23rd, 3:00 ­ 4:30 PM; and
               Water Street at Union Street on Tuesday July 23rd, 3:00 ­ 4:30 PM.

    The "Five Corners" intersection was counted by MVC on Saturday July 20, 2013 from 10:00 AM ­
    12:00 AM, coinciding with our counts performed at the same intersection (from 11:00 to 12:00).
    Comparing the MVC count to that collected by the Proponent, for the only overlapping hour, 11:00 AM
    ­ 12:00 PM, our counts were higher than the MVC counts as can be seen by review of the Appendix
    material.

    Additionally, the intersections of Main Street at Union Street and Water Street at Union Street were
    counted by the MVC during the same timeframe on a weekday as our counts performed at the same
    intersections (from 3:00 ­ 4:30 PM). Comparing the MVC counts to those collected by the Proponent,
    for the overlapping hour and a half, our counts were higher than the MVC counts at the intersection of
    Main Street at Union Street, and lower than the MVC counts at the intersection of Water Street at
    Union Street. For the weekday evening peak hour, the counts at these intersections by both the MVC
    and the Proponent were lower than the January 2013 counts at these locations projected to peak season
    using the 66% adjustment factor from the May TIAS. However, they were notably higher for the
    Saturday midday peak hour at the intersection of Water Street at Union Street. Further investigation of
    the volumes was necessary to determine why these were generally the only counts in the study area that
    were higher than the previous counts. Given the location, the most likely explanation for the increased
    volume is that if the municipal parking lot was full, vehicles were using the parking loop to reverse
    direction to circulate and wait for a parking spot or wait to pick someone up at the ferry. Under future
    conditions, the addition of parking for the Stop & Shop would alleviate this condition.

    The Martha's Vineyard Commission (MVC) also completed ATR counts within the month of July at
    the following locations and times:

               Main Street July 1st ­ July 8th;
               South Main Street west of Camp Street, July 8th ­ July 15th;
               Beach Road near Five Corners, June 28th ­ July 5th and July 8th ­ July 15th;
               Union Street near Main Street, July 8th ­ July 15th; and
               Lagoon Pond Road near PO, July 8th ­ July 15th.




    \\vhb\proj\Providence\72451.00\docs\memos\Response To HSH Revised Peer Review.docx 
                         Date:  July 30, 2013                                                                                                                                3 
                         Project No.:  72451.00 
                               
                              These ATR counts were compared to other past ATR count performed by MVC. The data recorded in
                              July 2013 was overall lower than the data recorded in July/August 2009 and August/September 2010
                              for the weekday evening peak hour. For the Saturday midday peak hour the 2013 July data ranged from
                              2% to 36% higher than the counts completed in 2009 and 2010, with the exception of Union Street.
                              The Union Street counts were consistently lower in July 2013 than in past years.

                              As shown in Table 1, the critical movements at all of the study area intersections currently operate at an
                              acceptable LOS D or better under 2013 Existing conditions with the exception of the Five Corners
                              intersection. Similar levels of operation are expected under future No Build and Build conditions, with
                              the exception of the Water Street at Municipal Lot Driveway / Steamship Egress intersection. The



                              \\vhb\proj\Providence\72451.00\docs\memos\Response To HSH Revised Peer Review.docx 
Date:  July 30, 2013                                                                                          4 
Project No.:  72451.00 
      
    Steamship Egress driveway currently operates at LOS D during the 2013 Existing weekday evening
    peak hour and LOS C during the 2013 Existing Saturday midday peak hour. The intersection operates
    at LOS D during both No Build peak periods. Based upon discussion with the Town regarding the
    proposed site plan and the layout of the Municipal Lot, the existing Norton Lane access to Water Street
    will be closed under the Build condition. The closure of Norton Lane provides the opportunity for
    traffic calming (slowing of vehicles in the municipal lot), minimizing the circulation of vehicles within
    a street (east Norton Lane), provides enhanced separation of pedestrians from through-moving vehicles,
    and enhanced landscaping/street-scaping treatments. Given the direction that was provided to the
    Proponent by the Town, and the features that have been highlighted, the proposed plan represents a
    well-balanced enhancement to this area. However, as a result, all traffic exiting the Stop & Shop and
    Municipal Lot must use the existing Municipal Lot driveway, and the addition of vehicles turning right
    from the Municipal Lot to Water Street south degrades the LOS to an F during the Build peak periods.
    However, it should be noted that during peak activity times, the Steamship Authority egress operates
    under police officer control, which is not reflected in the analysis results summarized in Table 1 and
    results in more efficient operations. The Proponent is open to participating in the cost of the police
    details at the Steamship Authority Egress/Municipal Lot to offset project impacts and will work with
    the MVC to determine the appropriate level of participation.

    Safety Information
    Comment: The Applicant provided the crash rate calculations using MassDOT's calculation sheets, as
    requested. The crash rate per million entering vehicles (MEV) for Five Corners is 1.01/MEV, which is
    1.74 times the average crash rate for MassDOT District 5, which for unsignalized intersections is
    0.58/MEV. Nearly half of the crashes were either rear-end or head-on crashes; surprisingly, there
    were only 4 injury crashes at Five Corners. Given that there is already a safety issue at this location,
    the Applicant should consider what safety improvements could be made to the intersection to mitigate
    their additional traffic. It should also be noted that the crash rate at the intersection of Water
    Street/Union Street has a crash rate of 1.95/MEV, or 3.36 times the District 5 average crash rate. The
    intersection only averages one crash per year, but it is a low volume intersection, which causes the
    crash rate to be higher.

    Response: We agree with the peer consultant that the crash frequency, under existing conditions, is
    substantially higher than the MassDOT District 5 average. We also agree that an assessment of relative
    safety should be conducted. The Proponent is willing to assist the town, MVC, and the State by
    funding a traffic safety audit of the Five Corners location as mitigation for the project, assuming that all
    state and local permits are obtained and project proceeds.


    Site Traffic Generation and Distribution
    Comment: We are comfortable with the Applicant's trip generation methodology based on the
    additional detail provided, with the exception of the application of a seasonal adjustment factor, which
    we still find problematic based on the lack of additional data to support the lower adjustment rate (see
    response to item #2, Traffic Data Collection). The Applicant should review the trip generation rates
    once the new count data are collected, as requested in comment 2. We will provide additional comment
    on the trip generation once new traffic count data are collected, as requested in comment 2.

    Response:

    As indicated previously, the July 2013 peak season traffic counts revealed that the seasonal growth
    factor from January to peak season is between 28 ­ 37% during the peak hour for the overall TMCs and
    45 - 46% during the peak hour for the ATR count. However, to remain conservative the seasonal



    \\vhb\proj\Providence\72451.00\docs\memos\Response To HSH Revised Peer Review.docx 
Date:  July 30, 2013                                                                                        5 
Project No.:  72451.00 
      
    adjustment factor of 1.39% that was utilized to bring the April 2013 trip generation counts to peak
    season will not be changed.

    Comment: We requested that the Commission ask the Applicant to reconsider that all up-island traffic
    would use Main Street to access the expanded store, and instead distribute traffic through the Five
    Corners intersection. The Applicant provided a sensitivity analysis of the operations for two different
    directional distributions ­ the first in which all left-turns from "up island" via State Road occur
    through Five Corners, and the second in which 20% of the turns occur at the State Road/Main Street
    intersection and 80% occur at Five Corners. The sensitivity analysis summary table appears to have
    some math errors in the eastbound left-turn demand estimates in the Build condition in both scenarios.
    Nevertheless, the sensitivity analysis is based on the Synchro analysis that we did not feel was the
    appropriate method for analyzing the Five Corners intersection given its unusual geometry and
    control; therefore we do not believe the results show anything meaningful in terms of the potential
    impact on Five Corners. We request that the Commission ask the Applicant to re-run the analysis using
    the VISSIM model for comparison with other scenarios and using the peak summer traffic count data.

    Response:

    For the purpose of providing a more in-depth sensitivity analysis, a supplemental VISSIM analysis has
    been completed. Two models have been re-run; one using both the original trip distribution pattern and
    one using the revised trip distribution, which sends 80% of both the net trips and pass-by trips through
    the Five Corners intersection, and just 20% of the trips up Main Street. The summarized analysis
    results are provided in Table 2 below. As shown in Tables 2 and 3. The analysis generally indicates,
    particularly with regard to queue lengths and overall delay, that the proposed project does not result in a
    substantial incremental impact at the Five Corners intersection. Similar to the results of the Synchro
    analysis, a drop in LOS to LOS F is experienced at the intersection of Water Street and the Municipal
    Lot/Steamship Authority Egress due to the geometric modifications and consolidation of traffic. Again,
    it should be noted that during peak activity times, the Steamship Authority egress operates under police
    officer control, which is not reflected in the analysis results summarized in the tables and results in
    more efficient operations.

          \\vhb\proj\Providence\72451.00\docs\memos\Response To HSH Revised Peer Review.docx 
Parking Demand
Comment: The Applicant provided an explanation of how the parking spaces in the garage will be
managed. According to this new information, the spaces in the garage will be for Stop & Shop
customers only; all others will be warned, to be following by towing of vehicles. We believe this
management plan coupled with the proposed reconfiguration of the Town parking lot will have the
effect of increasing demand on the Town parking spaces, leaving the proposed garage underutilized.
Anyone who might have planned a multi-purpose trip to patronize other shops and restaurants in
addition to Stop & Shop will not park in the garage lest their vehicle be towed. We recommend that the
Applicant work with the Town to implement a parking strategy that works to take advantage of shared
parking.

Response:

The existing Stop & Shop does not have any dedicated parking for customers and thus relies heavily on
the adjacent Town parking lot, which currently has 65 parking spaces available to the public. The new
proposed facility will have 43 parking spaces for Stop & Shop customers as well as 64 parking spaces
within the redesigned Town parking lot, which will represent a post development total of 107 parking
spaces in this area or an increase of 42 parking spaces in this area. As requested, the Proponent will
work with the town to development strategies to manage and enhance the shared parking opportunities
that will exist with the proposed plan in place.

Traffic Impact Analysis
7. Comment: The Applicant provided analysis of Five Corners for Existing and Build conditions using
   the VISSIM modeling tool. The results were summarized in tabular form. We reviewed the
   summaries and the output and viewed the videos that are an output from the model. Since the
   Applicant did not take new counts of the Five Corners intersection, it is unclear from the written
   response how the VISSIM model was calibrated. Typically, we would perform data collection and
   field observations of the following items in order to calibrate the existing conditions models:
         Volumes (origin-destination);
         Speeds: 50th and 85th;
         Vehicle composition (percentage of passenger vehicles/trucks/buses); and
         Conflict areas/priority rules (includes gap acceptance/headways/yield rules).

     We request that the Commission ask the Applicant to provide more detailed information regarding
     how the existing conditions models, which form the basis for the Build conditions models, have
     been calibrated.

     Viewing the video clips for each scenario, it appears that the videos don't show the full extent of the
     queuing. The queues on all approaches appear to extend beyond the viewport of the video. The
     reported queues in the summary table seem far below the anecdotal information we have received
     from the MVC staff regarding queuing. We believe this may be a function of the finite lengths of
     each street entering the intersection. For example, if Beach Road is only modeled as 500 feet long,
     this is the maximum queue that the program can report on that approach. Other items that we
     noted on viewing the videos of the simulations:
           The vehicles seem very aggressive when entering the Five Corners intersection. It appears
               that the gap acceptance and/or priority rules are set very low. Some vehicles almost hit
               each other and in some instances drive over each other. While it is true that motorists can
               be aggressive at this location due to the delays during the peak season, the video doesn't
               seem realistic.




\\vhb\proj\Providence\72451.00\docs\memos\Response To HSH Revised Peer Review.docx 
Date:  July 30, 2013                                                                                                9 
Project No.:  72451.00 
      
                     Although only three of the five approaches to the intersection are stop-controlled, the legs
                     that aren't stop-controlled tend to act as stop-controlled sometimes because a motorist on
                     an uncontrolled approach (Beach Road or Beach Street) aren't really sure how the
                     intersection is supposed to operate and who has a free movement and therefore the right of
                     way.
                     In the p.m. peak hour, the vehicles on Water Street going toward the Five Corners
                     intersection are leaving space at the Stop & Shop and Town parking lot driveways to allow
                     vehicles to enter, but there is a glitch in the model, because the vehicles are still not able to
                     enter the parking lot and are shown queuing in the northbound direction on Water Street.

         Five Corners is the most critical location in the study area. We and the MVC need to understand
         how the addition of approximately 150 new trips in the weekday evening and Saturday midday peak
         hours will impact this critical intersection. These trip numbers may increase based on our previous
         comments regarding the trip generation (see comment 7). The MVC is currently collecting peak
         season traffic count data for comparison to the seasonally adjusted volumes provided in the study.
         We have requested that the Commission ask the Applicant to conduct new traffic counts now that
         we are in the midst of the peak season. We request that the Commission ask the Applicant to use
         these new traffic data to re-run all analysis so that we may have a better understanding of the
         impacts, particularly at Five Corners. The Applicant should also collect the necessary data to
         calibrate the VISSIM model at Five Corners, which would then correspond to the new count data,
         and provide detailed information about how the model was calibrated.

    Response: Based on the comment, the Proponent has prepared supplemental VISSIM runs of the Five
    Corner intersection which consider adjustments that have been identified in the comment. Adjustments
    were also made based on a review of the video monitoring for the Five Corners intersection.
    Specifically some of the changes include the following:

               Vehicle Queues ­ Based on this comment as well as a review of the queue observations
               provided by the MVC, VHB extended the Beach Road approach to provide more queuing area
               to determine what impact it has on the analysis results. However, we did not extend it to
               capture the full extent of some of the queuing observed by the MVC. It should be noted that
               not all of the queuing at Five Corners is directly related to the flow of traffic through the
               intersection. Other factors such as nearby driveways, side streets, pedestrian crossings, and
               police control at the Steamship Authority driveway play a role. As noted by HSH, the link
               lengths can impact to maximum queue that is reported. However, if storage area is not
               provided for the entire queue length, it does not impact the other MOEs that are reported. In
               terms of documenting the actual queue lengths, we trust the accuracy of the MVC observations
               as well as anecdotal accounts from other Town officials, and our own observations. In terms of
               delays reported on each approach summarized in the tables above, the VISSIM runs provide
               that output independent of the length of the roadway segments drawn on the network.
               Modification Of Gap Acceptance ­ Based on a review of the July peak hour videos at Five
               Corners, the gap acceptance was generally modified to approximately the default values for all
               approaches except for Water Street because videos showed aggressive driver behavior.
               Stop Control Operations ­ Based on review of the July videos, VHB concurs with HSH that
               vehicles on the mainline often behave as if all five legs are under stop control at this
               intersection. As such, VISSIM runs were conducted assuming an all-way stop condition.
               However, this approach turned out to be too restrictive and the amount of volume being
               processed through the intersection was unrealistically low. To address the slow moving
               vehicles on the mainline, VHB added reduced speed areas on Beach Street and Beach Road to
               essentially model a rolling stop condition to account for this behavior.
               Intersection Blocking ­ Because the volumes counted in July 2013 are generally lower than the
               adjusted January 2013 volumes, the vehicle queues on Water Street did not block Norton lane


    \\vhb\proj\Providence\72451.00\docs\memos\Response To HSH Revised Peer Review.docx 
Date:  July 30, 2013                                                                                            10 
Project No.:  72451.00 
      
               as frequently in the latest analysis. This is consistent with our field observations as well as the
               videos, which generally showed blockage during the periods after a ferry arrived. As such, no
               modifications to the intersection blocking parameters were required.

    It should be understood that there are many, many inputs associated with the VISSIM software
    platform. Similar to the initial runs associated with the project, maintaining consistency (of inputs)
    between the existing and future conditions runs ensures that an assessment of project traffic is
    evaluated, even if there are varying opinions of adjustment factors under consideration. Similar to the
    initial VISSIM runs, calibration to the analyses were made based on reviewing the videos and based on
    observations that were made in the field (January and again in July). As outlined in the analyses,
    overall operations at the Five Corner intersection are substantially constrained during the weekday
    evening and Saturday Midday peak hour periods. The proposed project will add traffic to this location
    which amounts to 117 vehicles during the PM Peak Hour (6.6% increase) and 116 vehicles during the
    Saturday midday peak hour period (6.8%) increase. We do not believe that this level of increase will be
    noticeable to the traveling public. The results of the VISSIM analysis support this conclusion.


    Mitigation Measures
    Comment: We believe there are additional or revised analyses that may be necessary once the peak
    summer traffic data have been collected and reviewed. We will revisit the issue of mitigation measures
    once that effort is complete.

    Response:
    As indicated previously, both the VHB and MVC July 2013 peak season traffic counts revealed that the
    actual peak season traffic volumes were generally lower than our originally projected peak volumes.
    However, in order to provide an accurate peak season volume network, 2013 Existing Conditions base
    volumes were updated to reflect the July 2013 peak season counts (unadjusted). The results of both the
    Synchro and VISSIM intersection operational analyses are summarized in the tables provided above.
    As outlined in the tables, the change between the 2013 Existing and the Build conditions is relatively
    minor, as would be expected given the marginal traffic increases expected as a result of the proposed
    project.


    Construction Period Traffic
    Comment: The Applicant provided a narrative regarding construction period activities and how they
    will be managed. We recommend that the MVC require that the Applicant provide a formal submission
    of a Construction Management Plan, including to-scale drawings that show the limits of work, lay-
    down areas, etc., to ensure that there is no impact on the adjacent Town parking lot.

    Response:
    The Proponent believes that the proposed site and adjacent municipal parking lot modifications
    represents the best plan moving forward which is responsive to town officials' requests. Once
    agreement on this plan is provided, the requested construction phasing plans will be prepared. Such
    plans will require substantial coordination with the Town of Tisbury and the Proponent, and the Town
    will ensure that any parking area disruption will be minimal and occur during non-peak periods.


    Site Access
    Comment: The Applicant has revised its site access plan to remove the site egress driveway from the
    garage on Water Street. Access to the garage is provided via Norton Lane, where a driveway would


    \\vhb\proj\Providence\72451.00\docs\memos\Response To HSH Revised Peer Review.docx 
Date:  July 30, 2013                                                                                       11 
Project No.:  72451.00 
      
    provide both access and egress. This driveway would be aligned with the center aisle of the public
    parking area located across Norton Lane. The proposed site plan also reconfigures the Town parking
    lot, eliminating Norton Lane completely. We do not believe this is advantageous to the Town, as the
    Applicant has indicated that they will not allow a shared parking strategy of management of their
    garage. The site plan, as currently shown, eliminates any separation between the Town parking lot and
    the building, making the two properties feel like one parcel. As outlined in the comments regarding
    parking demand and management (see comment 9), this would only work for general users of the Town
    lot if the Stop & Shop garage parking spaces were also shared during store hours. We do not believe
    the MVC should support this proposal given the Applicant's proposal for management of its own
    garage. We believe that patrons will be less likely to use the garage if they have multi-use trips
    planned, i.e., visiting shops/restaurants on Main Street prior to doing their shopping at Stop & Shop,
    which will put a greater burden on the Town parking lot.

    The Applicant also states that the closure of Norton Lane would be advantageous to the Town because
    it would eliminate a conflict point on Water Street and allow longer queuing distance from Five
    Corners. However, this change would also mean that motorists traveling to and from the Steamship
    Authority to pick-up or drop off ferry passengers would no longer have a straight route to the ferry
    using Norton Lane. Instead they would have to wind through the parking area, turn right onto Water
    Street, then left into the Steamship Authority pickup/drop off area. This could cause some of them to
    change their usual route and travel through Five Corners instead, increasing the burden on that
    intersection.

    Response:

    As addressed previously, under the proposed development the public parking lot will be reconfigured to
    include 64 parking spaces. Additionally, many Stop & Shop customers will now be able to park in the
    garage, freeing up parking spaces within the Town parking lot, whereas currently the patrons of Stop &
    Shop must share a 65 space parking lot with the rest of the public. As mentioned at the public hearing
    and in previous correspondence, the current site plan and municipal parking lot configuration was
    developed based on discussion and direction provided by Town of Tisbury officials. Given the desire
    to try and balance the parking, access/circulation, and pedestrian needs in this area this plan is a
    reasonable approach at striking this balance. The plan will make the vehicular movement from Main
    Street to Water Street slightly less direct, as the reviewer has suggested. However this change indirectly
    results in traffic calming (slowing of vehicles in the municipal lot), minimizes the circulation of
    vehicles within a street (east Norton Lane), provides enhanced separation of pedestrians from through-
    moving vehicles, and enhanced landscaping/street-scaping treatments. Given the direction that was
    provided to the Proponent by the town, and the features that have been highlighted, the proposed plan
    represents a well-balanced enhancement to this area,

    Truck Traffic / Loading
    Comment: The Applicant provided additional information regarding loading activities such as
    deliveries and trash/recycling pickup. The Applicant indicated that there would be up to 13 delivery
    vehicles per day to the expanded store, including one tractor-trailer truck per day to the site. The
    Applicant provided the AutoTURN analysis for large vehicles using the loading area to demonstrate
    that a large vehicle can maneuver in and out of the loading docks. We have concerns regarding site
    access (see comment 13), but the figures provided indicate that the loading docks, and site layout can
    accommodate the appropriate sizes of trucks as currently configured.

    Response:

    No further response required.



    \\vhb\proj\Providence\72451.00\docs\memos\Response To HSH Revised Peer Review.docx 
Date:  July 30, 2013                                                                                          12 
Project No.:  72451.00 
      

    Comment: We commented previously on a proposed layout of the Town parking lot in concert with the
    expansion of Stop & Shop. The Applicant has since put forth a revised proposed plan to reorganize the
    public parking lot located across Norton Lane from the Stop & Shop site. The plan eliminates several
    spaces from the Town lot, as well as the Town comfort station. We do not believe this plan is
    advantageous to the Town unless the Applicant proposes to share the Stop & Shop parking garage
    spaces with all patrons of Vineyard Haven shops and restaurants. This revised plan seems primarily to
    benefit the Applicant's ability to access the loading docks. Although this plan would eliminate a
    conflict point at Water Street/Norton Lane, we otherwise do not see the benefits to the public parking
    and access.

    Response:
    The removal of the comfort station was something that was suggested to the Proponent by Town
    officials as it has a substantial cost to maintain and there are other opportunities for these services in the
    immediate area (Police Station and at Stop & Shop). Under the redevelopment plan, the Proponent is
    providing an enhanced restroom area within the store that is available to the public. Since the last
    hearing the Proponent has worked to relocate the restrooms within the Stop & Shop store from the
    southeast portion of the building near Water Street to the entrance area that fronts the municipal parking
    lot. By relocating to this area the new location will be very much proximate to the existing location of
    the comfort station (within 50 feet). Therefore if the town desires to remove the comfort station and
    save the maintenance fees, there is a good option available to the public for similar services.

    In addition, there have been comments made the Proponent requires removal of the comfort station in
    order for the delivery trucks to have access to the loading dock area. Simply put, this is not true. Refer
    to Figures 1a, 1b, and 1c which show ingress and egress to the loading dock area assuming that the
    comfort station remains where it is.
